title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: We then cross the Carron near Aquherie, and enter the woods of Fetteresso.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: On emerging from an immense cutting through the solid rock, the line enters the valley of the Carron water, with the woods of Dunnottar and Cannount Hill on the right, and the lands of Fetteresso on the left.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: having on our left the valley, woods, and Castle ofFetteresso.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: Our route for some time contained nothing wecould look on with pleasure, tiU after windingthrough a succession of slightly cultivated fields, andbarren moorish hills, upon ascending a considerablebank, the expanse of the German Ocean opened besore our delighted gaze ; while, on descending intothe vaUey which contains Stonehaven, the termination of the great valley of Strathmore — which isso contracted at the Water of Bervie, as to seemto end there — the fine lawns and extensive woodssurrounding the tall, white castle of Fetteresso,(Colonel Duff,) and nearer still, the groves of

title: To arms! :
author: Balfour, Andrew
snippet: We found him in miserable quarters at a place called Fetteresso, and I shall never forget my first meeting with a royal personage.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 1 "He went from Fetteresso to Brechin, on Monday, 2d ofJanuary ; stayed there till Wednesday, when he came lo Kinliaird; went 'to Glamis on Thursday, and on Friday, abouteleven in the morning, he made his public entry into Dundee,with a retinue of about 34)n men on horseback, having the Earlof Mar on his right, and the Earl of Marischal on his left.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: They found him atFetteresso, discomposed with the ague,—a bad disorder to bring to a field of battle.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Theyfound him at Fetteresso, discomposed wilh the ague,—a bad disorder to bring to a field of battle.

title: Tours in Scotland 1677 & 1681. By T. Kirk and R. Thoresby. Edited by P. Hume Brown
author: Kirk, Thomas
snippet: 2 Elsick House, in the parish of Fetteresso, belonged to the family ofBannerman.
